title: Tropical Storm Hone : Hawaii faces flooding and road closures as three Cyclones stir in Pacific
message:
Tropical storm Hone brings heavy rain to HawaiiImpact on Big IslandPrecautions against future fires amid Tropical Storm HoneHurricane Gilma and Tropical Storm Hector gain strengthThree tropical cyclones were active in the Pacific Ocean on Monday, bringing varied effects to different regions.
Tropical Storm Hone caused significant rainfall and flash floods in Hawaii , while Hurricane Gilma and Tropical Storm Hector were gaining strength and moving eastward.The impacts of these storms led to road closures and power outages to potential future flooding concerns.Tropical Storm Hone, pronounced "hoe-NEH," caused road closures, downed power lines, and damaged trees in parts of the Big Island , according to William Ahue, a forecaster at the Central Pacific Hurricane Center in Honolulu.
"No major damage that we know of yet," news agency AP quoted Big Island mayor Mitch Roth as saying.
Additionally, four schools on the Big Island were closed because of power outages and flooded roads.
"We were experiencing tropical storm winds and heavy pounding rain through the night."

title: Tropical Storm Hone moves past Hawaii as two other cyclones stay active in the Pacific Ocean
message:
HONOLULU (AP) — Three tropical cyclones swirled over the Pacific Ocean on Monday, including Tropical Storm Hone which brought heavy rain to Hawaii, Hurricane Gilma which was gaining strength and Tropical Storm Hector which was churning westward, far off the coast of southern tip of Baja California.
“No major damage that we know of yet,” Big Island Mayor Mitch Roth said.
Four Big Island schools were closed because of power outages and flooded roads from Hone.
Gilma was located about 1,160 miles (1,865 kilometers) east of Hilo, Hawaii, and moving west at 8 mph (13 mph).
Farther to the east, Tropical Storm Hector also gained strength Monday.

title: Back - to - Back Hurricanes : Hawaii Could Face Gilma Less Than a Week After Hone
message:
Tropical Storm Hone began its pass of the islands as a Category 1 Hurricane on Aug. 25, diminishing to a tropical storm in the process.
National Hurricane Center's forecasted track for Hurricane Gilma on its way toward Hawaii as of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Aug. 26, 2024.
National Hurricane Center's forecasted track for Hurricane Gilma on its way toward Hawaii as of 5 p.m. Eastern time on Aug. 26, 2024.
National Hurricane Center/National Weather ServiceThe Hawaiian Islands could face back-to-back storms as the National Hurricane Center (NHC) forecasts Hurricane Gilma to arrive within striking distance by Labor Day Weekend—less than one week after Hurricane Hone.
There are currently three named storms in the Pacific, with Tropical Storm Hector following behind Gilma.

title: Magnitude 5 . 9 earthquake recorded off coast of Darwin
message:
A powerful magnitude 5.9 earthquake has been recorded off the coast of Darwin.
The earthquake was recorded in the Banda Sea with a depth of 62km at about midday on Tuesday.
The powerful quake just hours after a magnitude 3.0 tremor hit Victoria's Gippsland region 190km south-east of Melbourne at 7.54pm on Monday night.
Meanwhile, residents in NSW's Upper Hunter region and beyond were rattled by a magnitude 5.0 earthquake just after 12pm on Friday.
It came just hours after a magnitude 3.2 earthquake shook the nearby town of Muswellbrook at 1.10am with another magnitude 2.5 quake felt at 2.30am.

title: No more  wildfires of note  burning in B . C .
message:
There are no longer any "wildfires of note" burning in British Columbia, with the B.C.
The Corya Creek wildfire, about 170 kilometres northeast of Terrace, B.C., was the last fire to be tagged with the label, which was lifted on Monday.
Fire information officer Emilie Peacock cautions the changing status doesn't mean the wildfire season is over.
More than 10,000 square kilometres of land has been burned in B.C.
Last year's record wildfire season saw more than 28,000 square kilometres of land burned and forced the evacuations of communities in regions including the Okanagan and Shuswap.

title: Forecasters monitoring disturbance in Atlantic after weeks of relative calm
message:
After weeks of relative calm in the tropics, forecasters are monitoring a disturbance in the central Atlantic that could slowly develop over the next week.
Forecasters gave the disturbance a 0% chance of developing over the next 48 hours and a 20% chance of doing so over the next week.
The next named storm in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season will be Francine.
• • •Tampa Bay Times hurricane coverage 20245 things to know about the 2024 hurricane season, according to forecasters.
Forecasters predict ‘extremely active’ 2024 hurricane season.

title: Pretty scary : Tropical Storm Hone lashes parts of Hawaii Island as a Cat 1 hurricane
message:
(HONOLULU) - Tens of thousands of Hawaii Electric customers were without power across the state as Tropical Storm Hone moved through the islands over the weekend.
It upgraded to a Category 1 Hurricane late Saturday as it brushed the southern point of Hawaii Island on Sunday.
As of late Sunday evening, Hone was downgraded back to tropical storm as it pulled away from the islands.
At 11:30 a.m. Sunday, roughly 18,000 HECO costumers were without power across the state, the majority of them on Hawaii Island.
Hawaii Island residents can report damages from Hurricane Hone here or call (808) 935-0031.

title: Impacts of the drought across the Shenandoah Valley
message:
For a second year in a row, the Shenandoah Valley is facing the worst of it.
Four out of the top five Ag producing counties in the state, are in the Shenandoah valley.
An idea of how impactful the drought really is:For the Shenandoah Valley, 4 out of the top 5 Ag producing Counties are in the SV.
Soybeans instead of corn”Along the Shenandoah River is the Burnshire Dam in Shenandoah county.

title: Local farmers in desperate need of drought assistance
message:
HURRICANE, W.Va. (WSAZ) - An awareness meeting was held Monday in Hurricane to inform West Virginia farmers about programs to assist them during this historic drought.
Joshua Lewis, the District Director of the Farm Service Agency, spoke at the meeting, held at the Holiday Inn Express, to inform people of assistance available through the agency.
I mean, I know the big farmers has gotta have help, but us small farmers has to have help also,” Black said.
I put it on Facebook, had everybody to share it,” said Jeanette Waller, a local farm owner.
The Farm Service Agency said farmers have until the end of the calendar year to apply and need to make sure to keep all receipts to get accurate funding.

Epicenter of the earthquake was 66 km (41 miles) from Kangding (c. 100 000 pop).

title: Rain , cooler weather end campfire ban on Vancouver Island - Victoria Times Colonist
message:
Fire danger ratings across most of Vancouver Island are listed as very low, with some areas on the South Island listed as low.
Wildfire Service said recent rains and cooler temperatures will allow it to lift the campfire ban on Vancouver Island as of noon on Wednesday.
Fire danger ratings across most of the Island are listed as very low, with some areas on the South Island listed as low.
Wildfire Service said in a statement.
In last year’s record wildfire season, more than 28,000 square kilometres of land was burned, forcing the evacuations of communities in regions such as the Okanagan and the Shuswap.

message:

title: Disaster unemployment assistance available to Vermonters who lost work during July 9 - 10 flooding​
message:
The U.S. Department of Labor has approved federal disaster unemployment assistance for Vermonters who lost work because of the flooding from the remnants of Hurricane Beryl on July 9 and 10, the state Labor Department said Monday.
Last week, President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration for parts of the state that were hit by the flooding, including individual assistance disaster, which covers unemployment assistance, for residents in Addison, Caledonia, Chittenden, Essex, Lamoille, Orleans and Washington counties, the state said.
Heavy rains washed out roads in Vermont in the latest round of flooding to hit the state.
“Vermonters across the State have found their lives, homes, and businesses impacted again by this recent disaster,” Labor Commissioner Michael Harrington said in a statement.
The Labor Department will determine if the individual is eligible for regular unemployment or should apply for the federal benefit.

title: Clean - up efforts begin on Hawaii island as Hurricane Hone passes through
message:
HILO, Hawaii (KHON2) — Hawaii island is cleaning up from Hurricane Hone.
While no severe damages were reported, major roads remain closed and some have been without power since Saturday night.
Kauai County: No major impacts from Hone, monitoring looming storms in Eastern PacificFrom Kohala to Kau, Hone dumped over a foot of rain on parts of Hawaii island and some roads were damaged.
Some volcano residents had power back on by 9 p.m. on Sunday night.
The county is hosting two hazard mitigation meetings over the next two days where residents can provide comments and feedback.

title: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres issues climate SOS at earthquake - hit Tonga summit - as he warns that rapidly rising sea levels are  putting this Pacific paradise in peril
message:
The UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres has issued a climate SOS at the Tonga summit, warning that rising sea levels are 'putting this Pacific paradise in peril'.
He did this at a meeting of the Pacific Islands Forum, whose member countries are among those most imperilled by climate change.
It comes as a 6.6 magnitude earthquake rattled the opening day of the Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting.
Next month the United Nations General Assembly holds a special session to discuss rising seas.
United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres addressed Monday's opening ceremony, which celebrated the diversity of the region.

title: Severe storm threat in forecast for Chicago area this week – NBC Chicago
message:
The Chicago area is going to see near-record heat and oppressive humidity on Tuesday, but the threat of severe weather also exists, with gusty winds and heavy rain possible.
According to the Storm Prediction Center, the Chicago area is at a “slight” risk of severe weather Tuesday, with wind gusts up to 60 miles per hour and heavy rains possible.
Those readings could threaten records in Chicago, but more importantly could cause heat indices of 110-to-115 degrees across the area.
The threat of rain will continue into Wednesday, with isolated showers and thunderstorms possible throughout the day.
Stay tuned to the NBC Chicago app and the NBC 5 Storm Team for all the latest weather news and information.

title: B . C . lifts last  wildfire of note  designation as number of blazes drops below 300
message:
VANCOUVER — There are no longer any "wildfires of note" burning in British Columbia, with the BC Wildfire Service saying favourable weather had allowed crews to make good progress in the province's battle against hundreds of blazes.
The BC Wildfire Service dashboard on Monday afternoon showed the number of active blazes in the province had fallen to about 290, continuing a downward trend from Friday when there were about 340 fires burning.
The wildfire service update said B.C.

title: Iowa Mosquito Population Making Comeback | NEWSRADIO 1040 WHO
message:
Iowa State University entomologist Ryan Smith credits regular rains and flooding for the booming populations.
Iowa has more 50 types of mosquitoes.
Iowa State reports so this year, 19 mosquito samples have tested positive for WNV, and one human case reported (in Harrison County).
In 2023, 96 mosquito samples tested positive for WNV, and 17 human cases were identified.
Their presence can really be a problem, especially in northwest Iowa, a known hot spot for this type of WNV-carrying mosquito,” Smith said.

title: Storms drop significant amount of hail along South Coast - Boston News , Weather , Sports
message:
(WHDH) - Pop-up thunderstorms that hit parts of southern New England dropped a significant amount of hail on several South Coast communities Monday.
Videos and photos documented hail falling across the South Coast and Cape Cod.
The National Weather Service documented additional flooding in Dennis.
The National Weather Service issued several severe thunderstorm warnings and flash flood warnings Monday.
A larger severe thunderstorm watch was scheduled to remain in effect across much of southern New England until 7 p.m.Stay with 7NEWS on-air and online for the latest updates on severe weather.

title: The 2024 hurricane season is not dead : Ryan Phillips – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
The 2005 hurricane season was an extreme example of epic atmospheric performance orchestrated, in tandem, with epic fatigue for all who endured it.
It was 15 years later that a hurricane season combined the right ingredients to produce more storms (30) with more Gulf Coast landfalls than 2005.
The Hurricane season is on.
But as it stands, I’m left with a few sturdy reminders to share as we enter the heart of the season.
A late-August lull has produced doubt about what the second part of hurricane season may look like.

title: Emergency Declaration Issued For More Counties In New York State
message:
New York State issued another "Disaster Emergency."
Nearly two dozen Long Island homes have been determined to have major damage and roughly 17-hundred Suffolk County homes have some damage.
President Biden Approves Emergency Declaration for Suffolk CountyPresident Biden Speaks At West Point Commencement Getty Images loading...Late Sunday, Hochul announced that President Joe Biden had approved her request for a federal Emergency Declaration for Suffolk County.
"An Emergency Declaration can be declared for any occasion or instance in which the president determines federal assistance is needed," Hochul's Office states.
Kathy Hochul told the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation to issue an "emergency declaration" in nearly 20 counties.

title: Marin County supervisors green - light new Stinson Beach home
message:
A one-story, 1,296-square-foot house is proposed to be built on the last vacant waterfront plot in Stinson Beach.
Lauren Segal/Special to the ChronicleThe Marin County Board of Supervisors has denied efforts to block a proposed house on the last vacant beachfront property in Stinson Beach.
The proposed house has been assessed at a value of $3.6 million.
But in the intervening decades, concerns about environmentally sensitive habitat and sea level rise have made development more difficult.
“The county just paid for this great sea level rise study,” said Elizabeth Brekhus, a lawyer representing two neighbors, at the meeting.

title: Crabs , stingrays & fish dying in Little Sarasota Bay after Hurricane Debby
message:
SARASOTA, Fla. (WFLA) — Hurricane Debby dropped massive amounts of rain on Sarasota County, inundating some neighborhoods with feet of water.
Sarasota Bay Estuary Program Director Dr. David Tomasko said samples collected in Lower Sarasota Bay show run-off from the storm is impacting water quality in the area weeks later.
NHC monitoring potential tropical disturbance in AtlanticLast week, sampling conducting in Little Sarasota Bay found low to virtually no oxygen on the sea floor.
Tomasko said restoring the historic tidal connection would help flush pollutants out of Sarasota Bay after storms like Debby.
What we have seen in Little Sarasota Bay is the same thing we saw after Hurricane Ian and our water quality in Little Sarasota Bay is the worst part, even though it doesn’t get the greatest amount of runoff in the area.”The estuary program will be back out later this week to collect additional samples in lower Sarasota Bay.

title: Fires in Brazil Sao Paulo state under control : authorities
message:
Amid prolonged drought, Sao Paulo state is experiencing its worst month of August for fires in decades - Copyright Japan's Ministry of Defense/AFP HandoutFires that have razed thousands of hectares of forest in Brazil’s Sao Paulo state have been brought under control, authorities said Monday, though an alert for fresh blazes remained in place.
Since last Thursday, some 2,700 fires had been reported in the vast agricultural state, with more than 40 municipalities placed on high alert.
Amid prolonged drought, Sao Paulo state is experiencing its worst August for fires in decades, with more than 3,480 separate blazes identified, according to INPE, the National Institute for Space Research.
Several fires are still raging in the Brazilian Amazon, which is battling the largest number of blazes recorded in nearly two decades.
Experts and authorities say climate change has exacerbated the dry, hot conditions for fires, most of which are set illegally to clear land for agriculture.

title: How the Havasupai Tribe warns of flooding during monsoon season
message:
“We had multiple thunderstorms across the area, multiple warnings issued both Wednesday and again on Thursday,” said National Weather Service Flagstaff Meteorologist-In-Charge Brian Klimowski.
Given its location and limited access to cell service, the Havasupai Tribe says it does not have a warning system in place.
And that’s really what we rely on most heavily when something like this occurs,” said Havasupai Tribe Spokesperson Abbie Fink.
Last week’s monsoon was not the first time this area dealt with flooding.
Klimowski says it’s important to have an escape plan before hiking in a canyon or an area prone to flooding.

title: Suffolk County eyes FEMA funds to repair trail of storm damage
message:
Suffolk County officials said the dam would have to be replaced, joining a list of homes, roads and other facilities damaged by the record rainfall.
“What we're facing is an ecological, an environmental, and an economic disaster,” Suffolk County Executive Edward P. Romaine told Newsday on Monday.
What to know Suffolk County officials are eyeing federal emergency funds to repair or replace infrastructure damaged during last week's storms.
are eyeing federal emergency funds to repair or replace infrastructure damaged during last week's storms.

title: Power outage update : Hawaiian Electric working to restore power to 1 , 902 on Big Island , 64 in Upcountry Maui , and 62 on Oʻahu : Maui Now
message:
Hawaiian Electric crews continue work to restore power to the remaining customers impacted by Tropical Storm Hone.
As of 10:30 a.m., power restoration continued at the following locations:On Hawaiʻi Island, power has been restored to customers in North Kohala, Volcano and Punalu‘u.
Customers in these areas are urged to call the Hawaiʻi Island Trouble Line at 808-969-6666 if they are still without electricity.
On Maui, crews are working to restore most of the remaining 64 Upcountry customers later today.
Even if customers don’t see crews in their area, HECO advises that work is being done to restore power to their communities.

title: Fires in Brazil Sao Paulo state under control : authorities
message: An email has been sent to with a link to confirm list signup.

title: What are all those black spots on the Sun ?
message:
The past few nights have been prime opportunities to witness something we call “sunspots”, splotches of black dots on the surface of the Sun.
They are inherently cooler than their surroundings, appearing as black splotches to us from ~93,000,000 miles away.
The Sun operates on roughly 11 year cycles where sunspot counts rise and fall throughout the cycle.
In fact, sunspot counts like we’re seeing haven’t been seen in over 20 years.
This has resulted in brief moments just before sunset where spots can be seen with the naked eye.

title: Milton water department continues to work on water discoloration
message:
MILTON, W.Va. (WSAZ) - On August 16, Milton residents turned on their water and brown-yellowish color came flooding out.
“I just don’t trust it,” Evans said.
“We just want clean water.
If we pay the bills they should have clean water.
They shouldn’t go to meetings to beg for clean water.”Evans says he doesn’t trust the water and drinks bottled water, but he knows change is not going to come overnight.

title: What is sea level rise and why does it matter to our future ?
message:
It is worth noting that ocean circulation patterns, such as the Gulf Stream, can lead to regional differences in sea level rise.
© Unsplash/Omar Eagle Sea level rise is threatening the tourism industry in places like St Lucia in the Caribbean.
Warmer water grows in volume, a process known as thermal expansion, which is a significant contributor to sea level rise.
What can be done to counter sea level rise?
How the UN helpsCountering sea level rise requires a comprehensive and internationally coordinated approach, which the United Nations is uniquely equipped to lead.

title: UN chief issues  SO for Pacific Islands worst hit by warming ocean
message:
"I am in Tonga to issue a global SOS – Save Our Seas – on rising sea levels," he said.
Water expands as it warms, contributing to sea level rise, he said.
"Pacific islands are uniquely exposed.
This is a region with an average elevation just one to two metres above sea level," Guterres said.
Without cuts to global emissions, the Pacific Islands can expect additional sea level rise of 15 cm (5.9 inches) by 2050 and 30 days a year of coastal flooding, he said.

title: UN chief warns of rising sea level risk to Islands
message:
United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said ocean temperatures are rising in the Pacific Islands at three times the rate worldwide, and its population was "uniquely exposed" to the impact of rising sea levels.
"I am in Tonga to issue a global SOS – Save Our Seas – on rising sea levels," he said.
"Water expands as it warms, contributing to sea level rise," he said.
This is a region with an average elevation just one to two metres above sea level," Mr Guterres said.
Without cuts to global emissions, the Pacific Islands can expect additional sea level rise of 15cm by 2050 and 30 days a year of coastal flooding, he said.

title: Celebrities Ignore Deadly Wildfire Smoke Engulfing Brazil Largest City Under Socialist President
message:
The current spread of wildfires, under socialist President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, is the worst in over a decade.
Most affected states are deep in the Brazilian Amazon, though the nation’s capital and Sao Paulo are also experiencing high levels of unhealthy air quality.
The state of Sao Paulo is facing the highest number of fire outbreaks since 1998, the first year that INPE began tracking Amazon fires.
As of Sunday, officials documented a record 3,482 fires in Sao Paulo this month, dwarfing the August previous record of 2,444 wildfires in 2010.
Lula’s Environment Minister Marina Silva reiterated the allegedly unprecedented nature of fires ravaging the swamplands of Sao Paulo at the emergency meeting.

title: Charges considered over yacht sinking
message:
Italian Coast Guards carry a body on a rescue boat in Porticello harbor near Palermo, with a third body at the back of the boat on Aug 21, 2024, two days after the British-flagged luxury yacht Bayesian sank.
[Photo/Agencies]Prosecutors in Italy say the sinking of the superyacht Bayesian off the coast of Sicily, that left seven people dead, could results in charges of manslaughter and negligent shipwreck.
The Financial Times newspaper reports that the boat went down rear first, suggesting that compartments at the back of the boat may have become flooded.
"The important thing is that when the yacht reaches the surface the sea must be calm.
The yacht should be recovered exactly as it is, in one piece, with the aim of maintaining it as intact as possible."

title: Flooding : Is it time to stop living in basements ?
message:
And that doesn’t take into account the largely overlooked human and social consequences on our communities of flooding.
From cellars designed to store coal, to basements converted into living environmentsIn the past, cellars were dark, damp, utilitarian spaces designed to store coal and other provisions.
The use of basements as living spaces has become a particularly popular practice in Québec, but also elsewhere in northeast North America.
By regulating the use of basements, it would be possible to significantly reduce the cost and consequences of damage.
By taking action, we will be helping to reduce inequalities and ensure a better living environment for all.

title: Artificial Intelligence Predicts Earthquakes With Unprecedented Accuracy
message:
Researchers at the University of Texas have developed an AI that predicted 70% of earthquakes during a trial in China, indicating potential for future quake risk mitigation.
AI Earthquake Prediction BreakthroughA new attempt to predict earthquakes with the aid of artificial intelligence has raised hopes that the technology could one day be used to limit earthquakes’ impact on lives and economies.
Trial Results and Global ImplicationsThe AI was trained to detect statistical bumps in real-time seismic data that researchers had paired with previous earthquakes.
Once trained, the AI gave its forecast by listening for signs of incoming earthquakes among the background rumblings in the Earth.
One of the next steps is to test the AI in Texas since the state experiences a high rate of minor- and some moderate-magnitude earthquakes.

title: Abilene experiences moderate drought as drought reaches largest extent in Texas since December 2023
message:
Abilene experiences moderate drought as drought reaches largest extent in Texas since December 2023ABILENE, Texas.
(KTAB/KRBC) – According to the Texas Water Development Board, Abilene is experiencing moderate drought conditions.
Drought in Texas reached its largest extent since December 2023, and an additional 20 percent is vulnerable to drought in the coming weeks.
The National Weather Service predicted that we won’t see any improvements any time soon.
At 7,900 acre-feet, the lake’s conservation storage sits at 533 acre-feet.
